questions.text: A patient presented with cough and fever since 7 days. The physician ordered a CT scan of the chest which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Consolidation describes increased lung attenuation sufficient to obscure bronchial walls and blood vessels (on non-enhanced CT). Patent airways can be identified by the endoluminal gas as an air bronchogram. Consolidation can be caused by any process that evacuates alveolar air such as pneumonia, when air is replaced by inflammatory exudate, or tumour, when air is replaced by tumour cells. The given image shows consolidation with air bronchograms.

  1. Emphysema will show cystic changes distributed throughout the lung parenchyma.
  2. Pneumothorax (plural: pneumothoraces) refers to the presence of gas in the pleural space which allows the parietal and visceral pleura to separate and the lung to collapse
  3. Pleural effusions are abnormal accumulations of fluid within the pleural space. It is seen as fluid in pleural space.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page number 104

questions.text: A patient presented with dyspnea on exertion and difficulty in breathing. On doing a Xray, the following image was obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary emphysema is defined as the "abnormal permanent enlargement of the airspaces distal to the terminal bronchioles accompanied by destruction of the alveolar wall and without obvious fibrosis"

CXR features

  • Hyperinflation
    • flattened hemidiaphragm(s): the most reliable sign
    • increased and usually irregular radiolucency of the lungs
    • increased retrosternal airspace
    • increased anteroposterior diameter of the chest
    • widely spaced ribs
    • sternal bowing
    • tenting of the diaphragm
    • sabre-sheath trachea
    • blunting of the lateral and posterior costophrenic angles
  • Vascular changes
    • a paucity of blood vessels which are often distorted
    • pulmonary arterial hypertension
      • pruning of peripheral vessels
      • an increased calibre of central arteries
      • right ventricular enlargement

A. Consolidation/Pneumonia describes increased lung attenuation sufficient to obscure bronchial walls and blood vessels (on non-enhanced CT). Patent airways can be identified by the endoluminal gas as an air bronchogram. Consolidation can be caused by any process that evacuates alveolar air such as pneumonia, when air is replaced by inflammatory exudate, or tumour, when air is replaced by tumour cells. The given image shows consolidation with air bronchograms.

D. Pneumothorax (plural: pneumothoraces) refers to the presence of gas in the pleural space which allows the parietal and visceral pleura to separate and the lung to collapse

C. Pleural effusions are abnormal accumulations of fluid within the pleural space. It is seen as fluid in pleural space.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page number:250

questions.text: A patient presented with palpitations and dyspnea. He gave a history of hemoptysis. On doing an X Ray, the following image was obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mitral valve stenosis is a valvulopathy that describes narrowing of the opening of the mitral valve between the left ventricle and the left atrium. Patients with mitral stenosis characteristically present with progressive dyspnoea that is precipitated by sudden changes in heart rate, volume status or cardiac output

Typical chest radiographic features include:

  • Left atrial enlargement
    • convexity or straightening of the left atrial appendage just below the main pulmonary artery (along left heart border)
    • double density sign: the right side of the enlarged left atrium pushes into the adjacent lung and creates an addition contour superimposed over the right heart
    • elevation of the left main bronchus and splaying of the carina
    • walking man sign on lateral projections
  • Upper zone venous enlargement due to pulmonary venous hypertension
  • Pulmonary oedema
  • Diffuse alveolar haemorrhage
  • Secondary pulmonary haemosiderosis, often difficult to appreciate on a plain radiograph
  • Pulmonary ossification, a late sign

B.Pneumothorax (plural: pneumothoraces) refers to the presence of gas in the pleural space which allows the parietal and visceral pleura to separate and the lung to collapse

A.Pleural effusions are abnormal accumulations of fluid within the pleural space. It is seen as fluid in pleural space.

D.Eventration of diaphragm shows elevated diaphragms.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, Radiopaedia.org, seventh edition, Page number:315

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Pneumoperitoneum (aeroperitoneum is a rare synonym 12) describes gas within the peritoneal cavity, often due to critical illness. An erect chest x-ray is probably the most sensitive plain radiograph for the detection of free intraperitoneal gas. Small volume of air can be identified on lateral decubitus films.

a.Hepatomegaly is increase in the size of liver which is seen as enlarged hepatic shadow.

b.Lateral Xray is also true to some extent but a more appropriate answer would be pneumoperitoneum

d.Scoliosis is lateral curvature of the spine.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page number:463

questions.text: What is the method of measurement used in the following condition?
questions.solution:
The Cobb angle is the most widely used measurement to quantify the magnitude of spinal deformities, especially scoliosis, on plain radiographs. Scoliosis is a lateral spinal curvature with a Cobb angle of >10°. The Cobb angle technique can also assess the degree of kyphosis or lordosis in the sagittal plane.

a. Callosal angle is used in diagnosis of Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus.

c. Acetabular angle is used in diagnosing developmental dysplasia of hip.

d. Hip knee angle is used for measuring alignment of the lower limbs.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page number:1886

questions.text: What is investigation shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is a non-invasive imaging technique to visualise the intra and extrahepatic biliary tree and pancreatic ductal system. It can provide diagnostically-equivalent images to ERCP and is a useful technique in high risk patients to avoid significant morbidity.

A. MRI brain is a specialist investigation that is used for the assessment of a number of neurological conditions. It is the main method to investigate conditions such as multiple sclerosis and headaches, and used to characterise strokes and space-occupying lesions.

C. MR cisternography is an MR imaging technique useful in evaluating abnormalities in subarachnoid cisterns. It is the intracranial equivalent to MR myelography and can similarly be non-contrast-enhanced

D. Magnetic resonance urography (MR urography) is a MRI study that predominantly used to image congenital abnormalities of the urinary system. There are two types of MR urography: static fluid-sensitive urography that is heavily T2-weighted to image the fluid-filled urinary system and excretory MR urography that is T1-weighted that image the urinary system after intravenous gadolinium administration

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page number:656

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Acute appendicitis is an acute inflammation of the vermiform appendix. It is a very common condition in general radiology practice and is one of the main reasons for abdominal surgery in young patients.

On USG

Findings supportive of the diagnosis of appendicitis include 5:

  • target (Bull's eye) sign on transverse view indicates bowel wall thickening in the context of acute inflammation 41
    • fluid-filled hypoechoic centre
    • echogenic submucosa
    • hypoechoic muscularis propria
  • aperistaltic, non-compressible, fluid-filled blind-ending tube
  • >6 mm outer diameter (ultrasound measurements are 1-2 mm less than CT measurements) 34
  • hyperechoic appendicolith with posterior acoustic shadowing
  • identification of wall layers
    • normal 5 layers imply non-necrotic (catarrhal appendicitis)
    • loss of wall stratification implies necrosis
    • gas locules in appendicitis indicate gangrene
  • periappendiceal hyperechoic indurated fat (>10 mm) surrounding a non-compressible appendix with a diameter >6 mm
  • periappendiceal complex fluid collection
  • periappendiceal reactive lymphadenopathy
  • wall thickening (3 mm or above)
    • mural or extramural hyperaemia with colour flow Doppler increases the specificity
    • vascular flow may be absent in a necrotic segment
  • alteration of the mural spectral Doppler envelope 16
    • may support diagnosis in equivocal cases
    • a peak systolic velocity >10 cm/s suggested as a cutoff
    • a resistive index (RI) measured at >0.65 may be more specific

A.Intussusception is a condition in which a part of intestine telescopes into the other segment.

Ultrasound signs include:

  • target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)
  • pseudokidney sign
  • crescent in a doughnut sign
  • absent blood flow in the intussusceptum (a contraindication to enema reduction)
  • free fluid within the intusussceptum
  • a lead point within the intussusceptum mass eg a lymph node

C.Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis is a congenital condition in which there is hypertrophy of the pylorus which then results in progressive gastric outlet obstruction.

D.Normal ovary looks as a solid organ with numerous follicles.

Reference: Grainger and Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page number:527

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Epidural Hematoma (EDH) Formation:

  • Location: An epidural hematoma occurs between the inner table of the skull and the outer periosteal layer of the dura mater.
  • Appearance: It typically has a convex (lens-shaped) appearance on CT scans. This convexity results from the tight adherence of the periosteal dura to the skull, which prevents the hematoma from spreading into the subdural space.
  • Association: EDHs are commonly linked with a fracture of the temporal part of the skull and are often caused by injury to the middle meningeal artery.
  • Origin: Because EDHs are generally arterial in origin, they tend to present as hyperdense (bright) areas on unenhanced CT scans due to the higher density of arterial blood compared to venous blood.
  • Symptoms: Patients with EDHs may develop symptoms rapidly due to the arterial nature of the hemorrhage, which can lead to a quick accumulation of blood and increased intracranial pressure.

B.Subarachnoid hemorrhage is seen in subarachnoid spaces.

A.Subdural hemorrhage is seen in subdural layer

D.Intraparenchymal hemorrhage appears within the brain parenchyma

Reference: Grainger and Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page number 1387

questions.text: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteosarcomas are malignant bone-forming tumors. They are the second most common primary bone tumor after multiple myeloma.

Typical appearances of conventional high-grade osteosarcoma include:

  • medullary and cortical bone destruction
  • wide zone of transition, permeative or moth-eaten appearance
  • aggressive periosteal reaction
    • sunburst type
    • Codman triangle
    • lamellated (onion skin) reaction: less frequently seen
  • soft-tissue mass
  • tumor matrix ossification/calcification
    • variable: reflects a combination of the amount of tumor bone production, calcified matrix, and osteoid
    • ill-defined "fluffy" or "cloud-like" compared to the rings and arcs of chondroid lesions

A.Osteochondroma can be either sessile or pedunculated and is seen in the metaphyseal region typically projecting away from the epiphysis. There is often associated broadening of the metaphysis from which it arises. The cartilage cap is variable in appearance. It may be thin and difficult to identify, or thick with rings and arcs calcification and irregular subchondral bone.

C.Chondrosarcoma is a malignant cartilaginous tumor arising from the bones. It is characterised by rings and arcs calcification.

D.Melorheostosis, also known as Leri disease, is an uncommon mesenchymal dysplasia manifesting as regions of sclerosing bone with a characteristic dripping wax appearance (a.k.a. flowing candle wax appearance).

Reference: Grainger and Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page number:1041

questions.text: What is the name of classification used in this pathology?
questions.solution:
Given Xray shows fracture through the physes. The classification used for it is Salter and Harris. It was proposed by Salter and Harris for classification.

A.Neer classification is used for humeral neck fractures.

B.Mayo classification is used for olecranon fractures.

D.Fazekas grading is used for assessing chronic small vessel ischemic changes.

Reference: Grainger and Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page number:1935

questions.text: Given below is a triphasic images of a focal liver lesion. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hepatic hemangiomas or hepatic venous malformations are the most common benign vascular liver lesions. They are frequently diagnosed as an incidental finding on imaging, and most patients are asymptomatic.

Most hemangiomas are relatively well-defined. The dynamic enhancement pattern is related to the size of its vascular space 1. Features of typical lesions include:

  • Non-contrast: Often homogeneous hypoattenuating (<20 Hounsfield units) relative to liver parenchyma 23
  • Late arterial phase: typically show discontinuous, nodular, peripheral enhancement (small lesions may show uniform enhancement)
  • Portal venous phase: progressive peripheral enhancement with more centripetal fill-in
  • Delayed phase: further irregular fill-in and therefore iso- or hyper-attenuating to liver parenchyma

B.HCC is a malignant tumor arising from the hepatocytes and is characterised by early arterial enhancement on CT and rapid washout on venous phases. LIRADS is used for it’s classification.

C.Hepatic cysts are benign non enhancing cystic lesions in the liver.

D.Cholangiocarcinoma is a malignant tumor arising from the biliary epithelial cells.

Reference: Grainger and Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page number:598

questions.text: Ground glass appearance of the lungs is seen in:
questions.solution:
• Several chest CT findings have been reported in more than 70% of RT-PCR test-proven COVID-19 cases, including ground-glass opacities, vascular enlargement, bilateral abnormalities, lower lobe involvement, and posterior predilection.

Fig. GGO in COVID pneumonia

  • In COVID-19 endemic regions, the observation of these chest CT findings should raise the suspicion of possible COVID-19 diagnosis.
  • Chest radiographs may be normal in early/mild disease
  • The most frequent findings are airspace opacities, whether described as consolidation or, less commonly, GGO. The distribution is most often bilateral, peripheral, and lower zone predominan. In contrast to parenchymal abnormalities, pleural effusion is rare.
  • The following chest CT findings have been reported to have the highest discriminatory value:
  • peripheral distribution
  • ground-glass opacity
  • bronchovascular thickening (in lesions)

Reference: Grainger and Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page number: 104

questions.text: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hyperparathyroidism is the effect of excess parathyroid hormone in the body. It can be primary, secondary, or tertiary.

  • subperiosteal bone resorption
    • classically affects the radial aspects of the proximal and middle phalanges of the 2ndand 3rd fingers
    • medial aspect of tibia, femur, humerus
    • lamina dura: floating teeth (not specific)
  • subchondral resorption
    • lateral end of the clavicles
    • symphysis pubis
    • sacroiliac joints
  • subligamentous resorption
    • ischial tuberosity
    • trochanters
    • inferior surface of calcaneus and clavicle
  • intracortical resorption: cigar/oval-shaped or tunnel-shaped radiolucency in the cortex
  • terminal tuft erosion (acro-osteolysis)
  • rugger jersey spine
  • osteopenia
  • brown tumors
  • salt and pepper sign in the skull (pepper pot skull)
  • chondrocalcinosis

A.Paget disease of the bone is a common, chronic metabolic bone disorder characterized by excessive abnormal bone remodeling. The classically described radiological appearances are expanded bone with a coarsened trabecular pattern.

On xray, the spine shows picture frame pattern.

B. There are no specific findings in vertebra seen in hypoparathyroidism

D. Osteopetrosis: Marble bone disease(sclerotic bone seen)

Reference: Grainger and Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page number:1087
